page.title: 3.5.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will compute and interpret the correlation coefficient for a bivariate, numerical data set.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the strength of a relationship between two variables.

  • Use technology to find the correlation coefficient and explain what the value tells you about a linear model in everyday language.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 3.5.1: Using Bivariate Data in Context
  • 3.5.2: Finding and Using Correlation Coefficient to Interpret the Strength of Linear Relationships
  • 3.5.2: Self-Check
  • 3.5.3: Using Correlation Coefficient to Describe Relationships between Two Variables
  • 3.5.3: Self-Check
  • 3.5.4: Interpreting the Sign and Numerical Value of a Correlation Coefficient

After that, you‚Äôll practice and review.

  • 3.5.5: Practice
  • 3.5.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 3.5.1: Using Bivariate Data in Context
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Match the variables to the scatter plot you think they best fit. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

ùë•  variable ùë¶  variable
1. daily low temperature in Celsius for Denver, CO boxes of cereal in stock at a grocery in Miami, FL
2. average number of free throws shot in a season basketball team score per game
3. measured student height in feet measured student height in inches
4. average number of minutes spent in a waiting room hospital satisfaction rating

A

B

C

D



Enter the scatter plot that matches row 1 here:

The answer is C.



Enter the scatter plot that matches row 2 here:

The answer is B.



Enter the scatter plot that matches row 3 here:

The answer is A.



Enter the scatter plot that matches row 4 here:

The answer is D.

page.title: 3.5.2: Finding and Using Correlation Coefficient to Interpret the Strength of Linear Relationships
page.contents:
Activity

Priya takes note of the distance the car drives and the time it takes to get to the destination for many trips.

distance (mi) ( ùë• x ) travel time (min) ( ùë¶ y )
2 4
5 7
10 11
10 15
12 16
15 22
20 23
25 25
26 28
30 36
32 35
40 37
50 51
65 70
78 72

1. Distance is one factor that influences the travel time of Priya's car trips. What are some other factors?

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

 

Traffic, stop signs, stop lights, refueling, whether the driver is in a hurry, driving on surface streets or interstate.



2. Which of these factors (including distance) most likely has the most consistent influence for all the car trips? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

 Distance is the most consistent influence since it is always part of the reason a trip will take the time it does. The other factors, like stop lights, are only a factor sometimes since you may hit all green lights one day and all red lights the next day.



3. Use technology to create a scatter plot of the data and add the best fit line to the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

\(y=0.93x+4.15\) \(r=0.99\)



4. What do the slope and \(y\)intercept for the ‚Äúline of best fit'' mean in this situation?>

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

The slope represents the number of minutes it takes to drive one additional mile using the linear model. Assuming the linear relationship continues, the y-intercept represents the number of minutes it takes to drive zero miles; this may account for things like time getting ready or warming up the car before driving.



5. Use technology to find the correlation coefficient for this data. Based on the value, how would you describe the strength of the linear relationship?

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

 \(r=0.99\). Since r is near 1, the linear model fits the data very well.



6. How long do you think it would take Priya to make a trip of 90 miles if the linear relationship continues? If she drives 90 miles, do you think the prediction you made will be close to the actual value? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

It would take Priya about 88 minutes. I think the estimate will be good, because the correlation coefficient is very close to 1, so the model fits the data very well. I used the equation \(y=0.93x+4.15\) and figured out that y was 87.85 minutes by substituting 90 miles for x.

page.title: 3.5.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Determine the correlation coefficient of the data in the table below to 3 decimal places  and interpret the value.

\(x\) 8 15 26 31 56
\(y\) 23 41 53 72 103

answer.answer_text: \(r = -0.987\); there is a weak negative relationship.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: The slope of the points in the table is positive so the correlation coefficient should be positive. R-values close to 1 or -1 show strong relationships. The answer is \(r=0.987\); there is a strong positive relationship.

answer.answer_text: \(r=0.987\); there is a weak positive relationship.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: R-values close to 1 indicate a strong relationship.  The answer is \(r=0.987\); there is a strong positive relationship.

answer.answer_text: \(r=0.987\); there is a strong positive relationship.
answer.response: That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: Using graphing technology, ensure that you enter the data correctly. The slope of the points in the table is positive and the points are close to the line, so the correlation coefficient should be a positive number close to 1.

answer.answer_text: \(r=-0.987\); there is a strong negative relationship.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: The slope of the points in the table is positive so the correlation coefficient should be positive. The answer is \(r=0.987.\)

page.title: 3.5.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Calculating and Interpreting Correlation Coefficients

Properties of the correlation coefficient:

  • Property 1: The sign of ùíì (positive or negative) corresponds to the direction of the linear relationship.
  • Property 2: A value of ùíì = +ùüè indicates a perfect positive linear relationship, with all points in the scatter plot falling exactly on a straight line.
  • Property 3: A value of ùíì = ‚àíùüè indicates a perfect negative linear relationship, with all points in the scatter plot falling exactly on a straight line.
  • Property 4: The closer the value of ùíì is to +ùüè or ‚àíùüè, the stronger the linear relationship.

Using the data of shoe length in inches and height in inches for ùüèùüé men, find the correlation coefficient of the data with graphing technology.

\(x\) (Shoe Length) Inches \(y\) (Height)
Inches
12.6 74
11.8 65
12.2 71
11.6 67
12.2 69
11.4 68
12.8 70
12.2 69
12.6 72
11.8 71


The correlation coefficient is r ‚âà 0.65.

Based on the table, there is a moderate positive linear relationship between shoe length and height.

The table below shows how you can informally interpret the value of a correlation coefficient

If the value of the correlation coefficient is between... You can say that....
\(r-1.0\) There is a perfect positive linear relationship.
\(0.7\leq r<1.0\) There is a strong positive linear relationship,
\(0.3\leq r<0.7\) There is a moderate positive linear relationship.
\(0<r<0.3\) There is a weak positive linear relationship.
\(r=0\) There is no linear relationship.
\(-0.3<r<0\) There is a weak negative linear relationship.
\(-0.7<r\leq-0.3\) There is a moderate negative linear relationship.
\(-1.0<r\leq-0.7\) There is a strong negative linear relationship.
\(r=-1.0\) There is a perfect negative lineat relationship.


Try It: Calculating and Interpreting Correlation Coefficients

Consumer Reports published a study of fast-food items. The table and scatter plot below display the fat content (in grams) and number of calories per serving for ùüèùüî fast-food items.



Fat
( \(g\) )

 Calories
(kcal)
2 268
5 3003
3 260
3.5 300
1 315
2 160
3 200
6 320
3 420
5 290
3.5 285
2.5 390
0 140
2.5 330
1 120
3 180

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

The correlation coefficient is \(r‚âà0.44\). By the table, this indicates a moderate, positive linear relationship between sodium content and calories.

 

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 3.5.3: Using Correlation Coefficient to Describe Relationships between Two Variables
page.contents:
Activity

For each situation, describe the relationship between the variables, based on the correlation coefficient. Make sure to mention whether there is a strong relationship or not as well as whether it is a positive relationship or negative relationship.

1. Number of steps taken per day and number of kilometers walked per day.  \(ùëü=0.92\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a strong, positive relationship. An increase in the number of kilometers walked tends to go along with an increase in the number of steps taken per day.



2. Temperature of a rubber band and distance the rubber band can stretch.  \(ùëü=0.84\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

 There is a strong, positive relationship. An increase in temperature tends to go along with an increase in the distance a rubber band can stretch.


3. Car weight and distance traveled using a full tank of gas.  \(ùëü=-0.86\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a strong, negative relationship. An increase in the weight of a car tends to go along with a decrease in the distance it can travel on a full tank of gas.


4. Average fat intake per citizen of a country and average cancer rate of a country.  \(ùëü=0.73\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a strong positive relationship. An increase in the fat intake per citizen of a country tends to go along with an increase in the average cancer rate of a country.


5. Score on science exam and number of words written on the essay question.  \(ùëü=0.28\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a weak, positive relationship. An increase in the number of words written on the essay questions tends to go along with an increase on the score for a science exam, but the relationship is weak.


6. Average time spent listening to music per day and average time spent watching TV per day.  \(ùëü=-0.17\) 

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a weak, negative relationship. An increase in the average time spent listening to music per day tends to go along with a decrease in the average time spent watching TV per day, although the relationship is weak.


A biologist is trying to determine if a group of dolphins is a new species of dolphin or if it is a new group of individuals within the same species of dolphin. The biologist measures the width (in millimeters) of the largest part of the skull, zygomatic width, and the length (in millimeters) of the snout, rostral length, of 10 dolphins from the same group of individuals.

x, rostral length (mm)

y, zygomatic width (mm)

288

147

247

147

268

171

278

177

258

168

272

184

272

161

258

159

273

168

277

166

 

The data appears to be linear and the equation of the line of best fit is  \(ùë¶=0.201ùë•+110.806\)   and the  \(r\) -value is 0.201.

 

  1. After checking the data, the biologist realizes that the first zygomatic width listed as 147 mm is an error. It is supposed to be 180 mm. Use technology to find the equation of a line of best fit and the correlation coefficient for the corrected data. What is the equation of the line of best fit and the correlation coefficient?

  2. Compare the new equation of the line of best fit with the original. What impact did changing one data point have on the slope,   \(y\) -intercept, and correlation coefficient on the line of best fit?

  3. Why do you think that weak positive association became a moderately strong association? Explain your reasoning.

  4. Use technology to change the  \(y\) -value for the first and second entries in the table.

    1. How does changing each point's   \(y\)-value impact the correlation coefficient?

    2. Can you change two values to get the correlation coefficient closer to 1? Use data to support your answer.

    3. By leaving  (288,180)  , can you change a value to get the relationship to change from a positive one to a negative one? Use data to support or refute your answer.

Enter your answers here:

  1. \(ùë¶=0.693 ùë•‚àí18.373\)   and  \(ùëü=0.76\) 

  2. The slope increased and the correlation coefficient got closer to 1. The  \(y\) -intercept also change significantly.

  3. I think it became moderately strong because the data point that was changed did not follow the roughly linear pattern of the other 9 data points, and when it was changed, it did follow the linear pattern more closely.

    1. Changing the points to numbers well above or below the existing linear trend in the data makes the correlation coefficient get closer to zero.
    2. Sample response: I managed to get the  \(r\) -value to 0.86 by changing the 2 values that appeared furthest from the line of best fit,   ( 272 , 184 )  and  (272,161) , to values that are very close to the existing line of best fit,  (272,168)   and  (272,168) .
    3. Sample response: By changing  (247,147)   to  ( 247 , 1000 ) , I was able to change the relationship to a negative one because the line of best fit had a negative slope,  \(ùë¶=-14.187ùë•+4071.1 \)

page.title: 3.5.4: Interpreting the Correlation Coefficient
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Doctors suspect a strain of bacteria found in the hospital is becoming resistant to antibiotics. They put various concentrations of antibiotic in petri dishes and add some of the bacteria to allow it to grow. The bacteria grow into groups in the dish called colonies. After some time, the doctors return to the petri dishes and count the number of colonies for the different amounts of antibiotic.

The data is plotted with a best fit line. The correlation coefficient was \(r=-0.83\).


1. What does the sign of the correlation coefficient tell you about the relationship between the number of bacteria colonies and the concentration of antibiotic in the dish?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a negative relationship between the number of bacteria colonies and the concentration of antibiotics in the dish. When the concentration of antibiotics is higher, there are fewer bacteria colonies.



2. What does the numerical value of the correlation coefficient tell you about the relationship between the number of bacteria colonies and the concentration of antibiotic in the dish?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The relationship between the number of bacteria colonies and the concentration of antibiotic in the dish is strong since this value is fairly close to -1.



In a follow-up study, a group of scientists collect data that was fit by a linear model with a correlation coefficient of \(r=-0.94\). Which study suggests a stronger relationship between the number of bacteria colonies and the concentration of antibiotics-the doctors' study or the scientists' study? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The scientists' study suggests a stronger relationship, since both correlation coefficients are negative and the correlation coefficient for the scientists' line is closer to -1.

page.title: 3.5.3: Self Check
page.contents: In the graph below, which BEST describes the scatter plot of points?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: The slope of the line of best fit would be negative, so correlation should be negative. Also, the correlation coefficient is close to 1, so it is a strong relationship. The answer is \( r=-0.90 \), strong, negative correlation.

answer.answer_text: \( r=-0.90 \), strong, negative correlation
answer.response: That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: The slope of the line of best fit would be negative, so the correlation should be negative. Also, since the points are close together, the \( r \) value is close to -1.

answer.answer_text: \( r=-0.24 \), weak, negative correlation
answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Since the points are close together, the r value should be close to -1. The answer is \( r=-0.90 \), strong, negative correlation.

Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: The slope of the line of best fit would be negative, so correlation should be negative. Since the points are close together, the \( r \) value should be close to -1. The answer is \( r=-0.90 \), strong, negative correlation

page.contents:

a.     Using graphing technology, enter the chirps in the x-column of the table and the temperature in the y-column of the table. The correlation coefficient is  r=0.9509.

b.     This value is very close to 1, which suggests a strong, positive,  linear relationship.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

\(r=‚àí0.9985\),The relationship is a strong and negative relationship.

 

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I'd like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next lesson.

page.title: 3.5.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the strength of a relationship between two variables.
  • Use technology to find the correlation coefficient and explain what the value tells me about a linear model in everyday language.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 3.5.1: Using Bivariate Data in Context
    • In this activity, you matched bivariate data with its context. You thought about whether there would be a strong correlation or not as well as whether the relationship was a positive or negative correlation.
  • 3.5.2: Finding and Using Correlation Coefficient to Interpret the Strength of Linear Relationships
    • In this activity, you used technology to find a correlation coefficient given data and used it to interpret the strength of the linear relationship in context. In addition, you interpreted the coefficients of the equation of the line of best fit and used the equation to make predictions.
  • 3.5.2: Self-Check
  • 3.5.3: Using Correlation Coefficient to Describe Relationships between Two Variables
    • In this activity, you used the correlation coefficient to describe the relationship between two variables. You examined a pair of variables and a correlation coefficient to describe the relationship between the variables as strong or weak and as positive or negative.
  • 3.5.3: Self-Check
  • 3.5.4: Interpreting the Correlation Coefficient
    • In this activity, you described what the sign and numerical value of the correlation coefficient tell you about the strength of the linear relationship.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 3.5.5: Practice


Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you‚Äôve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 3.5.5: Practice
page.contents:
1. The number of hours worked, x, and the total dollars earned, y, have a strong positive relationship.

Explain what it means to have a strong positive relationship in this situation.

Correct! As the number of hours worked increases, the total dollars earned increases.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is as the number of hours worked increases, the total dollars earned increases. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. The number of minutes on the phone and the customer satisfaction rating have a weak negative relationship.

Explain what it means to have a weak negative relationship in this context.

Correct! As the number of minutes the customer waits on the phone increases, the customer satisfaction rating decreases.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is as the number of minutes the customer waits on the phone increases, the customer satisfaction rating decreases. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. Use a graphing calculator to answer the questions. Technology required.

Correct! The line of best fit is y=1.25x-2.79, so the value of the correlation coefficient is r=0.96

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is; The line of best fit is y=1.25x-2.79, so the value of the correlation coefficient is r=0.96 You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. The Princeton Review publishes information about colleges and universities. The data below are for six public 4-year colleges in New York. Graduation rate is the percentage of students who graduate within six years. Student-to-faculty ratio is the number of students per full-time faculty member.

a. Calculate the value of the correlation coefficient between the number of full-time students and graduation rate. Let ùíô represent the number of full-time students and ùíö represent the graduation rate. Round to the nearest hundredth.

Correct! The correlation coefficient is ùíì ‚âà ùüé. ùüñùüë.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 3.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

Let ùíô represent the number of full-time students and ùíö represent the graduation rate. The correlation coefficient is ùíì ‚âà ùüé. ùüñùüë. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

b. Is the linear relationship between graduation rate and number of full-time students weak, moderate, or strong?

Correct! Based on the table presented in the lesson, the linear relationship between graduation rate and the number of full-time students is strong.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 3.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Based on the table presented in the lesson, the linear relationship between graduation rate and the number of full-time students is strong. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

c. Calculate the value of the correlation coefficient between the student-to-faculty ratio and the graduation rate. Round to the nearest hundredth.

Correct! The correlation coefficient is ùíì ‚âà ùüé.ùüóùüì.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 3.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The correlation coefficient is ùíì ‚âà ùüé.ùüóùüì. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
